column1: Petaling Jaya (commonly called "PJ" by locals) is a city in Petaling District
column2: in the state of Selangor
column3: Malaysia. Originally developed as a satellite township for Kuala Lumpur
column4: the capital of Malaysia
column5: it is part of the Greater Kuala Lumpur area. Petaling Jaya was granted city status on 20 June 2006. It has an area of approximately 97.2 square kilometres (37.5 sq mi).

column1: Petaling Jaya is surrounded by Kuala Lumpur to the east
column2: Sungai Buloh to the north
column3: Shah Alam
column4: the capital of Selangor
column5: and Subang Jaya to the west and Bandar Kinrara (Puchong) to the south.

column1: The city was developed during post-war British Malaya on a piece of 1
column2: 200 acres (486 ha) rubber estate
column3: the Effingham Estate
column4: around Old Klang Road to address the overpopulation of the capital Kuala Lumpur in the 1950s. Since 1952
column5: PJ witnessed a dramatic growth in terms of population size and geographical importance. The development of Petaling Jaya commenced in 1952 with the construction of 800 houses centred on the area known as "Old Town" today.Lieutenant-General Sir Gerald Templer (then the British High Commissioner of Malaya and Petaling District council chairman) planned for Petaling Jaya to be a satellite town to prevent people from assisting the communists; the earlier housing areas were fenced off from the surrounding area. The first two main roads built in Petaling Jaya were simply called "Jalan 1" or Road 1 and "Jalan 2" or Road 2. Road 1 was later named Jalan Templer while Road 2 was named Jalan Othman after Othman Mohamad
column6: former Menteri Besar (Chief Minister) of Selangor.Until the end of 1953
column7: the town was administered by the Kuala Lumpur district officer. The Petaling Jaya Town Authority headed by N.A.J. Kennedy commenced administrating Petaling Jaya in 1954. On 24 August 1959
column8: Encik Abdul Aziz bin Haji Mohd Ali became the first Malayan to head the PJ Authority. Administratively and historically
column9: it was considered part of Kuala Lumpur. However
column10: Petaling Jaya ceased to be part of Kuala Lumpur when the latter became a Federal Territory on 1 February 1974. It then became a township in its own right within the state of Selangor.Southern Petaling Jaya
column11: from Section 8 to PJ Old Town
column12: had the first settlements that were established around 1953. As development progressed
column14: on the other side of the Federal Highway was developed. The first shopping complex in Petaling Jaya was Jaya Shopping Centre (better known as Jaya Supermarket). Built in 1974

column2: following the passing of the Local Government Act the previous year
column3: the Petaling Jaya Town Authority was reorganised to become Petaling Jaya Municipal Council or Majlis Perbandaran Petaling Jaya (MPPJ). Petaling Jaya progressed rapidly due to the massive rural-urban migration. As more people from rural areas immigrated
column4: Sungai Way and Subang districts along with areas such as Subang Jaya
column5: Seksyen 52 (New Town or colloquially known as "State"
column7: former cinema in the area) developed in areas under the jurisdiction of the municipality.

column3: USJ

column3: or the movement control order (MCO)

column2: the market in the city's oldest quarter
column3: Old Town

column2: large parts of Old Town came under a full government lockdown on May 10 after the discovery of 26 Covid-19 cases from the market area. Over 2
column3: 900 people in the quarter were fenced in and prevented from leaving the area
column4: as authorities cordoned off 40ha of the area with barb wire from the rest of the city. Scheduled to last until May 23
column5: the lockdown was eventually lifted on May 21 .

column1: After a lull in cases thanks to a nationwide lifting of restrictions
column2: the city began to see a rise in cases in October following a spike in virus infections after infections rose in the eastern state of Sabah
column3: where elections were held in September.

column1: Over 800 people working at the Tropicana Golf and Country Resort were barred from leaving their hostel
column2: as authorities put the compound under a total lockdown . Five people there tested positive for the virus
column3: including two who had just returned from the eastern state of Sabah .

column1: In the first two weeks of the month
column2: at least four malls in the city reported Covid-19 infections. This included the 1Utama shopping mall
column3: which was ordered to close for seven days from October 12.

column2: a teacher at the Taman Sea secondary school also tested positive for the virus on October 7
column3: leading students and staff members there to self-quarantine. A few days later

column5: which include Petaling Jaya

column1: Petaling Jaya is one of the wettest cities in Malaysia. It is warm with an average maximum of 30 degrees Celsius and receives heavy rainfall all year round
column2: roughly more than 3
column3: 300 mm (130 in) of average rainfall annually. The city has no particular true dry season
column4: but June and July are the driest months. Mostly each month average rainfall receives more than 200 mm (7.9 in). Thunderstorms and extreme rainstorms are common
column5: and it is one of the highest lightning strike areas in the world. But due to normal global temperature variations
column6: Petaling Jaya is experiencing severe drought with frequent water rationing among neighbourhoods.

column2: Petaling Jaya was granted a city status and Dato' Ahmad Termizi Puteh
column3: a former Yang di-Pertua MPPJ
column4: automatically became the first mayor (Datuk Bandar) of Petaling Jaya. Petaling Jaya's local council changed its name to Majlis Bandaraya Petaling Jaya (MBPJ) or Petaling Jaya City Council following the granting of city status. On 15 August
column5: Dato' Ahmad Termizi Puteh retired from the post of mayor. He was later replaced by Dato' Hj. Mohamad Roslan Sakiman.

column1: The residents of Petaling Jaya are served by four Members of Parliament from Pakatan Harapan
column2: which is DAP's Tony Pua in Damansara
column3: PKR's Maria Chin Abdullah in Petaling Jaya
column4: PKR's Sivarasa Rasiah in Sungai Buloh and PKR's Wong Chen in Subang.

column1: Petaling Jaya is divided into several sections. Some are subdivided into smaller neighbourhoods (kejiranan)
column2: for example SS5D. Some sections have their own names (SS1 as Kampung Tunku)
column3: while other sections are grouped together (SS3
column4: SS4
column5: SS5
column6: SS6 and SS7 as part of Kelana Jaya). Besides that
column7: Petaling Jaya also comprises the affluent township of Damansara. Note that SS is not the same as Seksyen but as the short acronym for Subang-Sungai Way instead.

column2: Petaling Jaya claimed 613
column3: 977 residents living in the area of 51.4 square kilometres (19.8 square miles). The actual population by 2015 would have been a little over 550
column4: 000 residents without taking into account the total population of the Kuala Lumpur-Petaling Jaya conurbation which would have resulted in a total population of 1.5 million.

column1: A prominent landmark in PJ is the Kota Darul Ehsan arch which symbolically marks the boundary between Kuala Lumpur and Petaling Jaya. This arch straddled the Federal Highway (Lebuhraya Persekutuan) which was originally the only highway link between Petaling Jaya and Kuala Lumpur. However
column2: many links now exist as alternatives to the congested Federal Highway.

column1: Close to the Kelana Jaya Line's Taman Jaya station are the Petaling Jaya Museum
column2: as well as the Thai Wat Chetawan temple. This ornate building is very popular amongst the Buddhist community. A short drive ahead is PJ State
column3: the nickname for the Central Business District of Petaling Jaya with the landmark Menara MBPJ as a focal point. PJ State is more formally referred to as PJ New Town.

column1: Damansara is the main shopping hub of Petaling Jaya with many of the city's shopping malls being located there. Some of the notable shopping malls in the city include The Curve
column2: Ikea
column3: IPC Shopping Centre
column4: One Utama
column5: Tropicana City Mall

column1: The 1980s saw the establishment of shopping malls like The Atria in Damansara Jaya and Subang Parade in the nearby suburb or satellite town of Subang Jaya. The Atria provided the opportunity for residents to patronise either the Japanese Kimisawa or the French Printemps department stores
column2: as well as a Burger King restaurant.
1 Utama commenced operations at Bandar Utama. Jaya Jusco
column3: a Japanese department store which had operated since 1984 at Taman Tun Dr Ismail later relocated as one of the anchor tenants of 1 Utama.Tesco supermarket commenced operations in Mutiara Damansara in 2003. This was quickly followed by the Ikano Power Centre in 2004 and The Curve in 2005. The Ikano Power Centre (now renamed as IPC Shopping Centre since 2011) houses Southeast Asia's largest IKEA Swedish furniture store. At about the same time
column4: the 1 Utama new wing had commenced operations
column5: which then became the largest shopping mall in Malaysia (or currently number 11 largest shopping mall in the world).

column2: Giant Hypermarket commenced operations in Kelana Jaya. This complex houses the Giant Hypermarket and some shops to create a more shopping centre style. It is easily accessed off the Damansara–Puchong Expressway. Nearby is the SStwo Mall
column3: which was opened at the end of December 2010
column4: and Paradigm Mall
column5: which opened in mid-2012.

column1: Before the rapid development and commercialisation of Petaling Jaya
column2: there were only a handful of residential developments which comprises mostly low to medium-cost apartments as well as terrace houses. By 2005

column1: Transportation facilities and infrastructure are well developed in Petaling Jaya. Bus services were initially provided by Sri Jaya between the early 1950s until the early 1990s. Some SEA Park residents may recall the old Sri Jaya Leyland Albion buses on the No. 241 service struggling to climb the relatively steep Jalan 21/1.
The introduction of the IntraKota bus system by DRB-Hicom saw the replacement of Sri Jaya and the mini-buses by the early 1990s. At the same time
column2: some of the Petaling Jaya-Kuala Lumpur bus routes were serviced by Metrobus. The PJ City Bus operated by Petaling Jaya City Council has the same concept with CAT Penang (and Selangor Smart Bus in other region)
column3: which now provide 6 routes around Bandar Utama
column4: Damansara Damai and PJ Old Town.

column1: The introduction of the PUTRA LRT service in 1998 saw the addition of the Putraline feeder bus services. The combination of Putraline and Putra LRT brought a relief to many Petaling Jaya residents especially those who had to rely on public transportation.

column2: RapidKL took over the operations of IntraKota
column3: STAR and PUTRA LRT. Today
column4: public transportation is provided by RapidKL in the form of buses as well as the KL Light Rapid Transit System - Kelana Jaya Line. The line has seven (previously five) stations within Petaling Jaya.

column2: since 2017
column3: the newly constructed MRT Sungai Buloh-Kajang Line
column4: part of the KVMRT project
column5: runs through the northern part of Petaling Jaya's municipal area

column1: Petaling Jaya has three access points to the national highway system: North–South Expressway via Kota Damansara
column2: Damansara
column3: and Subang. Internally
column4: highways such as the Damansara–Puchong Expressway
column5: Sprint Expressway and the Federal Highway exist.

column1: Petaling Jaya is also served by the Subang Airport which is located immediately to the west of Petaling Jaya.

column1: The UiTM facility in Section 1 commenced life as the Dewan Latehan RIDA in November 1956. It was later renamed the Dewan Latihan MARA. This was a training centre under the auspices of RIDA or the Rural and Industrial Development Authority.  Essentially it was also the inspiration of Dato' Onn Jaafar
column2: the founder and former president of UMNO or the United Malays National Organisation. This UiTM facility can be regarded as Petaling Jaya's oldest college.There are 58 primary and 28 secondary schools in Petaling Jaya under the purview of Malaysian Ministry of Education including Sekolah Kebangsaan Kampung Tunku
column3: Sekolah Kebangsaan Kelana Jaya
column4: Sekolah Kebangsaan Sri Damai
column5: Sekolah Kebangsaan Kelana Jaya
column17: SMK (P) Taman Petaling and SMK Kelana Jaya. The oldest school in Petaling Jaya is likely the Road 10 Primary School in Old Town. The foundation stone of the school was placed by Sultan Hisamuddin Alam Shah in 1952.

column2: a German international school
column3: is in Petaling Jaya.Malaysia's first private nursing college is at Assunta Hospital in Petaling Jaya. The Tun Tan Cheng Lock College of Nursing was founded in 1961.

column1: Petaling Jaya has a fully equipped
column2: multi-purpose stadium known as Petaling Jaya Stadium. Petaling Jaya Stadium is the home of Petaling Jaya City F.C. in Malaysia Super League and has a capacity of 25

column1: The Football Association of Malaysia is also located in Petaling Jaya.
The Muslim community can pray at mosques such as those at Jalan Templer
column2: Section 17
column3: Section 14
column4: Section SS1 and Damansara Utama. Masjid Kelana Jaya Putera
column5: which was built in the late-2000s
column6: is located in Kelana Jaya. Masjid Jamek Sultan Abdul Aziz Shah at Jalan Templer is likely the oldest mosque in Petaling Jaya. This mosque was declared open by the Sultan of Selangor on 23 October 1964. Later in 2008
column7: the mosque was modernised and rebuilt.

column1: The Roman Catholic Christian community can attend mass at churches such as St Francis Xavier's
column2: located on Jalan Gasing
column3: which was established in 1961. Two other Catholic churches are the Church of the Assumption on Jalan Templer as well as St. Ignatius in Taman Mayang. The Assumption church is the oldest: it dates from 1959. The Trinity Methodist church dates from 2 August 1959 and is at Jalan 5/37. An Anglican as well as a Lutheran church is located at Jalan Utara. Glad Tidings Assembly of God church is at Jalan Bersatu 13/4. Several shophouse-based churches exist across Petaling Jaya. In 2005
column4: the former Ruby Cinema in SEA Park temporarily became the Damansara Utama Methodist Church. Harvest Community Church (an Assembly of God church) is located at D-1-36
column5: 8 Avenue Business Centre
column8: Petaling Jaya. Small "shoplot" churches can be found all around the city; some of these transform into larger churches
column9: like Grace Assembly PJ (an assembly of god church). These attract a larger following and can be found in many places around the city.

column2: Wat Chetawan along Jalan Gasing was built in 1957 and officiated by the late King Bhumibol Adulyadej
column3: the King of Thailand at the time. Chempaka Buddhist Lodge (千百家佛教居士林) is established since 1985
column4: is managed by lay Buddhist community and located at Taman SEA. Chinese Buddhist temples such as Poh Lum Fatt Yuen (寶林法苑) along Jalan Gasing and Kwan Inn Teng Temple (觀音亭) are also catered for the local Chinese Buddhist community. Hung Shing Temple (洪聖宫廟) and Yuen Leong Sing Fatt Temple (阮梁聖佛宮) fulfil the needs of the Taoist community. Other Chinese temples like Yuan Lin Xiao Zhot Buddhist Temple (园林小筑) and Sau Seng Lum Buddhist Temple (修成林) can also be found in PJ Old Town and in Section 11.

column1: The Sri Sithi Vinayagar Temple (Sanskrit: श्री सिद्धि)at Section 4 along Jalan Selangor serves as the main religious facility for Petaling Jaya's Hindu community. The main God worshiped here is Ganesh
column2: (Sanskrit: गणेश). Vinayaga is a common name for Ganesh. There is a Mariamman Temple in Jalan 17/47
column3: and the Geeta Ashram is a north-Indian style Hindu Temple dedicated to Krishna. The Geeta Ashram can be found in Lorong Utara B in Section 52.

column1: There is a Sikh Gurdwara located in Lorong Utara B
column2: beside the Tun Hussein Onn Eye Hospital and the Geeta Ashram.

column1: The city made international headlines on 13 February 2017 when Christian pastor
column2: Raymond Koh was ambushed on SS4B/10 by around fifteen men in SUVs and subsequently "disappeared". Koh led the Hope Community in Kuala Lumpur which helps the city's poor
column3: single mothers
column4: and drug addicts. In 2019
column5: the Human Rights Commission of Malaysia accused the Malaysian Special Branch of the abduction
column6: carried out because Koh was suspected of attempting to convert Sunni Muslims to Christianity.
